1.1 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES
Our commitment to Safety and Environmental Protection in the Air Liquide Large Industries US, L.P. (Air Liquide), El Segundo Hydrogen Plant must extend beyond the gates. As part of the community, we have a responsibility to our customers and to those who live in the surrounding area. Through safety, concern for the environment, and community involvement, we can develop a true partnership with our customers and neighbors.

1.2 MANAGEMENT SYSTEM FOR THIS RMP
Air Liquide (AL) has prepared this Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the stationary hydrogen production plant for its facility located at the Chevron El Segundo Refinery.  The RMP was developed and submitted to comply with Program 3 requirements of the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program pursuant to Title 19 of the California Code of Regulations (19CCR), Section 2735.6 and the Federal regulation 40 CFR 68.   Pursuant to 19CCR 2735.6 and 40 CFR 68, a management system has been developed for the site.  The Facility Manager has the overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of CalARP/RMP accident prevention program elements.  This position has direct supervisory responsibility for the operations and maintenance of the hydrogen production plant.  Key technical groups within Air Liquide support the development and implementation of some prevention program elements.  The operators and I&E technicians will be responsible for day-to-day operation and maintenance of the hydrogen facility.  An organizational chart for the facility as well as job descriptions can be found in the site procedure.

1.3 DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES
The AL plant is located at 1310 East El Segundo Blvd, El Segundo, California, 90245 on the Chevron Refinery property.  The facility?s mailing address is 214 Main St., El Segundo, California, 90245.  The Hydrogen Facility?s size is approximately 3.5 acres, and it

is located in the south east corner of the refinery.  The area directly east of the facility is predominately zoned for heavy industrial activities.  However, to the South, residential property is located within approximately 0.4 miles.  Also, no environmental receptors have been identified within this area. 
The products from the plant are hydrogen and steam.  The unit produces raw hydrogen, which is then purified.  
There are four types of feed stock for the unit: pentane, natural gas, refinery fuel gas, and anhydrous ammonia.  The plant is designed to operate for 9 months with pentane feed, refinery fuel gas, and ammonia. While the plant is to operate the remaining 3 months of the year with natural gas, refinery fuel gas, and ammonia feedstock.  Continuous operation with a mixture of all four types of feedstock is not foreseen.  The fuel for the reformer furnace is off-gas from the PSA unit, supplemented with refinery fuel gas or natural gas.
The pentane reformer feedstock meets the criteria for classification as a flammable mixture pursuant to the regulations at CCR Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Section 2770.2 (b)(2).  The total quantity of pentane flammable mixture present at the facility is 33,264 pounds.  The pentane flammable mixture consists of butane (CAS# 106-97-8), isopentane (CAS# 78-78-4), and pentane (CAS# 109-66-0). The predominant component in this mixture is isopentane.  The quantity of pentane, as a flammable mixture, exceeds the 10,000 pound threshold for both the EPA RMP and CalARP regulations.

1.4 HAZARD ASSESSMENT RESULTS
To meet the Federal RMP and the CalARP regulations, the Facility must analyze one worst-case release scenario that is estimated to create the greatest distance in any direction to the end point resulting from an accidental release of regulated flammable and toxic substances from covered processes under worst-case conditions.  Administrative controls and passive mitigation devices are present to mitigate off-site consequ

ences, however none of these devices were considered in the Worst Case Scenario (WCS).  Additionally, under the Federal RMP and the CalARP regulations, the Facility must analyze a most credible Alternative Release Scenario (ARS).  Historical data from Industry reportable chemical accidents were reviewed to ensure a credible event was chosen.  In the ARS passive mitigation was applied in the off-site consequence analysis.  All modeling was done with USEPA RMP*Comp version 1.07.

1.4.1 WCS Flammable
The pentane feedstock meets the criteria for classification as a flammable mixture pursuant to the regulations at CCR Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Section 2770.2 (b)(2).  The total quantity of pentane flammable mixture present at the facility is 33,264 pounds.  The pentane flammable mixture consists of butane, isopentane, and pentane.  The predominant component in this mixture is isopentane.  The largest quantity of this flammable mixture contained in a single location within the facility is at the pentane feed surge drum, V-100.  The maximum quantity of flammable mixture that could be contained in this vessel has been estimated at 30,272 pounds.  The worst-case scenario (WCS) associated with a flammable material at the plant is a catastrophic failure of the feed surge drum.  The WCS has been modeled such that the entire contents of this vessel are released as a vapor within 10 minutes.  

The estimated impacts (distance to endpoint) from the worst-case release scenario involving the flammable mixture extends to 0.2 miles.  Within this circle of 0.2 miles radius, there are no residential receptors.  However, there are public receptors located on the Chevron Refinery at the Isomax control room and offices.  The potentially affected number of receptors at these locations is 42.

1.4.2 WCS Toxic
There is no data to report.  The Facility does not have any toxics that exceed the 10,000 pound threshold for the EPA RMP regulation.
 
1.4.3 ARS Flammable
The ARS for flammable

s results from a flange leak on the bottom of the pentane surge vessel, V-100.  The flange leak is modeled at a release rate of 1010 pounds per minute based upon the release of the entire contents of the vessel into the dike area within 30 minutes.  The contents of the dike ignite resulting in a pool fire. 

The estimated impacts (distance to endpoint) from the ARS involving isopentane extends to 0.04 miles.  This distance is based on a heat radiation end point of 5 kilowatts per square meter.  Within this circle of 0.04 miles radius, there are no residential receptors.  However there are public receptors located on the Chevron Refinery at the Isomax control room.  The potentially affected number of receptors at this location is 14.

1.4.4 ARS Toxic
There is no data to report.  The Facility does not have any toxics that exceed the 10,000 pound threshold for the EPA RMP regulation.

1.5 GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS
In addition to the CalARP and EPA RMP regulations, processes at the Hydrogen Facility are also subject to the OSHA PSM standard.   The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at the El Segundo Hydrogen Facility.  This summary addresses each of the CalARP and EPA RMP prevention program elements. 

1.5.1 Employee Participation
Management alone cannot insure safety or protection of the environment. There should be no doubt that each employee must also demonstrate their concern and acknowledge their responsibility in these areas.  At the El Segundo Hydrogen Facility, employees are required to participate in process safety management and accident prevention.  Specific ways an employee can be involved in the accident prevention program are documented in the site procedure.  This procedure details the participation of employees in process hazard analysis (PHA), pre-startup safety reviews (PSSR), and being involved in incident investigations concerning the plant.   Plant employees are trained with the Proce

ss Safety Information, to include at least the following: (1) information pertaining to the hazards of the hazardous chemicals in the process, (2) information pertaining to the technology of the process, and (3) information pertaining to the equipment in the process.  Plant employees are involved in the review of process operating procedures to ensure they are correct and recommend any necessary changes.  The employees participate in monthly safety meetings where process safety and employee safety issues are discussed and corrective actions are developed.

1.5.2 Process Safety Information
A variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes are maintained at the site and at corporate offices.  These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, equipment design/configuration information, specific chemical inventories and operation limits for key process parameters.  The plant manager is responsible for maintaining up-to-date process safety information.  A table summarizing the reference documents and their location is readily available as part of the site procedure, which can be used by employees to locate any necessary process safety information. 
Chemical specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment consideration, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDSs) which are located in the control room or online on the corporate intranet.  The plant operating procedures and design data books provide information on the key operating limits for the process.  Plant operators are trained to operate the process using process controls and instrumentation within these operating limits.  
Along with operating procedures to provide safe initial start-up, normal start-up, normal operations, shutdown and emergency shutdown, the plant has extensive documentation on the design and construction of the plant components.  This information includes materials of construction, des

ign pressure and temperature ratings, and electrical ratings and documentation for the plant.

1.5.3 Process Hazard Analysis
AL has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled.  Within this program, a PHA shall be completed for each new and/or major modification to a facility or process prior to the initial startup or re-start.  This action will help define and correct process safety deficiencies in a proposed design for a new project or changes to existing facilities, refer to the corporate procedure.
The El Segundo Hydrogen Facility PHA was completed during 2003 during the design phase of the facility; the Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP) was used as the primary method of hazard analysis.  The HAZOP is the node by node method, described in the American Institute of Chemical Engineers (AIChE) Guidelines for Hazard Evaluation Procedures.   This method involves systematic evaluation of the process system by examining the causes and consequences of deviations from intended conditions, refer to the site procedure.
The PHA team consists of members with the appropriate experience to define the hazards and mitigating controls of the process and also represents a cross section of the employees working in the process.  The PHA team includes, but is not limited to, at least one person with specific experience in the subject process, one person knowledgeable in the PHA methodology being used, and one person with expertise in engineering.  The team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary.
Management reviews the PHA team findings and a resolution plan for each recommendation is put in place.  The plant manager is responsible for prioritizing and tracking implementation of the mitigation options.  The final resolu

tion of each finding is documented and retained.

1.5.4 Operating Procedures
The El Segundo Hydrogen Facility maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as initial start-up, normal start-up, normal operations, shutdown and emergency shutdown. These procedures will be used by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  These procedures are reviewed periodically and certified as required.  

1.5.5 Training
To compliment the written procedures for process operations, the El Segundo Hydrogen Facility has implemented a formal training program for all employees involved in operating the process.  New employees receive training on general orientation, site rules and practices, familiarization with the site, use of safety procedures and equipment, accident investigation and emergency procedures.  After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process specific duties and tasks.  In addition to the hands on work, classroom instruction is conducted on process safety information, standard operating procedures, safety consideration and the Emergency Action Plan.  Newly assigned operators must pass the operator training program and they are evaluated within 6 months.  After an operator has demonstrated adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently.  In addition operators are required to attend refresher course training that includes a review of standard operating procedures, HAZCOM, safe handling procedures and incident/accident procedures.  Training is documented and tracked in a training matrix for each operator.  Oral and written tests are used to verify that the operator understands the training.

1.5.6 Contractors
The El Segundo Hydrogen Facility uses contractors to supplement its own work force when maintenance activities exceed the capabilities or time available for the opera

tors.  Procedures are in place to make sure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inform the Hydrogen Facility personnel of any hazards that they find during their work.  This is accomplished by providing contractors with (1) a site overview, (2) information about the safety and health hazards of materials and processes on site, (3) emergency action plan requirements, and (4) safe work practices prior to their beginning work.  Contractors are evaluated to insure that both their safety performance and training required for work on the Hydrogen Facility site for employees meet the safety standards of AL.

1.5.7 Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)
AL ensures the safety of new/modified facilities or processes before placing those facilities or processes into service through the use of Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs).  PSSRs are intended to ensure safety through confirmation that: (1) construction and equipment are in accordance with design specifications; (2) safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place and adequate; (3) process hazard analyses (PHAs) have been performed and recommendations resolved before startup of new plants or processes; (4) management of change (MOC) requirements have been satisfied for modified facilities; and (5) training has been completed for affected employees.
This review shall apply to all new or significantly modified AL facilities and includes but is not limited to the following: (1) Any alterations, repairs, or replacement that are not within design specifications; (2) Physical changes and additions to existing systems and equipment including, but not limited to, piping, vessels, instrumentation, process control systems, safety systems, software, interlock systems and electrical syst

ems.  It may also include changes to structural components depending on their effect on the process; (3) Changes in process chemicals, catalysts, manufacturing processes or technology; (4) Software changes to control systems for equipment and processes.  A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.

1.5.8 Mechanical Integrity
The El Segundo Hydrogen Facility has established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief valve and vent systems, controls, pumps, compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition.  The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures.  In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment, which will help prevent and/or limit consequences of potential offsite impacts to the community.  The general maintenance philosophy of AL is that all maintenance be planned through preventative maintenance programs and performed during scheduled shutdowns.

1.5.9 Safe Work Practices
AL and the El Segundo Hydrogen Facility have safe work practices in place to help ensure employee and process safety.  These procedures comprise a group of corporate standards under the ?Life Safety? procedures implemented at all locations.  Procedures in place include:  (1) Energy Control and Isolation, (2) Safe Work Permit, (3) Hot Work Permit, and (4) Confined Space Entry Permit.  These procedures along with others maintained by the AL Health, Safety and Environmental department, along with training of affected personnel and periodic audits, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.

1.5.10 Ma

nagement of Change
AL has established requirements for ensuring that proposed process or equipment changes or changes indirectly affecting processes are evaluated, approved and documented prior to implementation through the use of a management of change (MOC) procedure.  This procedure outlines the requirements for documenting, evaluating the impact, and approving planned deviations from procedure.  The AL MOC system is a systematic process designed to help prevent inadvertent, unintended or unauthorized changes that may cause unsafe conditions, product quality problems, process hazards, unplanned outages, etc.  This standard also helps to ensure that changes are technically sound and that Quality and HSE safeguards originally designed into the facility are either maintained or enhanced. 

1.5.11 Incident Investigation
AL defines management systems and establishes the requirements for communicating, investigating and reporting of incidents at all facilities through the use of an Incident Investigation and Reporting procedure.  The purpose of incident investigation and reporting is to identify root causes and correct them rather than simply addressing the symptom of the incident.  Incident investigation and reporting is one of the primary methods used to continuously improve our operations by sharing information, identifying root causes, and implementing corrective actions, per the corporate procedure.   The plant manager is responsible for tracking significant incidents and corrective actions through completion.   Results of the incident investigation and corrective actions are shared with employees who could be affected by the findings.  Reports are retained for at least 5 years to be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA revalidations. 

1.5.12 Compliance Audits
To help insure the accident prevention program is functioning properly, the El Segundo Hydrogen Facility is audited by a team on a basis of at least every 3 years.  A team knowledgeable about the facility mu

st conduct the audit, but the majority of the team must not be involved in the day-to-day operations.  Recommendations and findings from the Audit team must be resolved in a timely manner.  The plant manager is responsible for obtaining engineering support to correct or modify the system based on the accepted recommendations.  Resolutions to these recommendations are documented.  Once the resolutions have been completed, communication of the corresponding changes is made to operating, maintenance and other employees whose work assignments are in the process and who may be affected by the recommendations or actions.  

1.6 CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
The processes at the El Segundo Hydrogen Facility have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation.  The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to the CalARP/RMP covered ammonia and pentane systems in the plant.  These prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by (1) equipment failures and (2) human errors.
In addition to the accident prevention program, the Hydrogen Facility has safety features designed to (1) quickly detect the release, (2) contain/control the release; (3) reduce the consequence of (mitigate) a release.  
The following types of safety features are used in various processes:

1.6.1 Release Containment/Control 
A containment dike has been installed to mitigate the release of pentane from the feed surge vessel, V-100 and another containment dike has been installed to mitigate the release of anhydrous ammonia from the anhydrous ammonia system.  A remote automatic fuse-able type isolation valve has been installed in the anhydrous ammonia line at the battery limits.  This valve can be closed from the control room.  This valve will automatically close due to a fire or a large pressure drop due to a leak.  

1.6.2 Release Mitigation
Twelve firewater monitors have been installed on the perimeter of the facility a

nd are capable of cooling the process equipment and knocking down ammonia vapor from a leak.  Fire extinguishers are also installed throughout the facility. There are three combination safety shower/eye wash stations in the facility as well. 
Personal protective equipment is located at the facility. Employees in the operating area wear personal ammonia and carbon monoxide monitors.  Also, a camera has been installed in order to monitor releases/spills/fires in the process area remotely from the control room.  

1.7 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
The facility has been recently constructed.  There have been no reportable accidents at the facility.   

1.8 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION
The El Segundo Hydrogen facility is designated as a non-responding plant, falling under section 40 CFR 68.90(b) with respect to the EPA RMP and under California Code of Regulations Title 19 Division 2 Chapter 4.5 section 2765.2 with respect to CalARP. The El Segundo Hydrogen Facility employees will only be trained to the First Responder Awareness Level, First Aid Fire Responder, and for First Aid and CPR.  The El Segundo Hydrogen Facility is located within the Chevron El Segundo refinery, and the facility, in cooperation with the refinery, has jointly reviewed the AL emergency action plan to insure appropriate action can be taken in the event of an accidental release.   The Refinery Emergency Responders will perform emergency response for Air Liquide in the event of an accidental release.    The procedure for activating the Refinery?s Emergency Notification System is found in the site Emergency Action Plan.  This document describes the coordination of response activities with local response agencies, outside agency notification procedures, and provides detailed evacuation procedures in the event of an ammonia release and/or fire.  
If an emergency occurs that will have off-site consequences, a Unified Command structure will be established based on the Chevron Refinery Emergency Resp

onse Plan.  The El Segundo Hydrogen Facility Emergency Response Coordinator will work with the Unified Command to ensure they are aware of the on-site hazardous materials and familiar with the El Segundo Hydrogen Facility Emergency Action Plan.

1.9 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The Hydrogen Facility is newly constructed, and all safety items were addressed in the PHA.  Subsequent updates to this document will include future safety improvements.
